review:
Decades later this is still a very unique game. Even among the very rare first person point-and-click genre. I won't pretend I don't have nostalgia for it from playing it in the 90s, but I've played it several times as an adult and truly think it holds up. The controls aren't very modern but getting used to them doesn't take long. The puzzles, in my opinion are only mildly abstract, and the average person shouldn't need to look anything up. The game oozes with style and is probably one of the most memorable experiences I've had playing hundreds of games over decades. 

My biggest advice: look up how to restore the American voice acting. Like many have said it better suits the mood of the game. And it's not even close.

review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
El juego es conocido por su atmósfera única y surrealista. Los jugadores se sumergen en un mundo distópico lleno de personajes extravagantes y entornos surrealistas. Esta peculiaridad ha sido elogiada por muchos, ya que proporciona una experiencia de juego inusual y memorable.

La trama y los diálogos han sido puntos destacados en las críticas. Los jugadores han disfrutado de la historia intrigante y de los personajes bien escritos que se encuentran a lo largo del juego. La narrativa, aunque un tanto extraña, ha sido considerada como uno de los aspectos más fuertes del juego.

En cuanto a los desafíos y rompecabezas, Normality ha sido elogiado por su nivel de dificultad equilibrado. Los rompecabezas son ingeniosos y requieren pensamiento lógico, lo que ha sido apreciado por los fanáticos del género de aventuras.

Sin embargo, algunas críticas se han centrado en los gráficos y la jugabilidad, que se consideran un poco anticuados en comparación con los estándares modernos. La falta de innovación en comparación con otros juegos de la época también ha sido señalada como un área de mejora.

review:
Hey gidi hey... Çocukluğumda bu oyunu hayal meyal oynadığımı, daha doğrusu oynamaya çalışıp ingilizcem olmadığı için beceremediğimi hatırladım. Oyuna girince başladığımız odayı görüp, arkaplandaki müziği duyunca "Bu oyun, oynayamadığım o oyun" dedi bilinç altım.

Windows 95 ve öncesi zamanlarda kaliteli oyun hep kendini belli ederdi. O zamanlar 3D kavramı yeni olduğundan, bu tarz point&click oyunlar akılda kalıcı olmuştu. Ama şunu da unutmamak lazım, 2000 ve öncesi yıllar bu tür macera-bulmaca oyunlarının revaçta olduğu dönemlerdi. O yüzden bana göre Normality diğer türdaş oyunlarının yanında silik kaldı.

Yıllar sonra gelen ücretsiz oyun keyiyle oyuna gireyim bakayım dedim. İlk 10 dakika nostalji hislerimi kabartmış olsa da sonrası baydı. Muhtemelen günümüz mekaniklerinin basitliğinden olsa gerek oyuna ısınamadım.

Alınıp oynanır mı? Meh... Belki benim gibi "Nerede o eski 90'lar" kafasındaysanız girip denersiniz.

review:
Normality is an ancient (1996) point and click adventure game with a similar gameplay style to the later Sierra Studios games (Space Quest 4, etc).  The game has a plot around everyone in the city becoming very apathetic and you need to solve puzzles to work out why.  Ok.  The game has a strong comedy theme. 

While the game "works", it's just way too old, with locked resolution and controls, very little in the way of game options.  The resolution looks like it's about 640x480 or something... it's heavily dated.

This would only be of interest to people who owned and played the game back in the 1990's, and since they already own it, Gremlin is trying to get people to pay for the same game twice, basically a nostalgia gouge.

As the old saying goes, you can't go home again.

review:
The visuals are still holding up rather nicely.
And the gameplay is still quite entertaining.
It's a game from 1996, with the 90s humor.
Some stuff feels outdated, some feels nice.
Most of the dialogues are really funny, tho.
If you like 'Old-School' point & click: Buy it.
Games like these are quite rare these days.
I always had a soft spot for the silly games.
And I do simply love the retro vibes as well.
It's just a dope nostalgic experience overall.
There's a surprising amount of bad reviews.
Most of them are complaining about audio.
Or rather: The us voice acting not featured.
I personally don't mind the uk voice actors.
Maybe because: I cannot compare the two.
Haven't actually played the said us version.
But: I understand that It can be a bit rough.
Especially if you grew up on the us version.
Personally: I'm just glad to see it on Steam.
And as such I had to give a positive review.

review:
I'd say... Mixed bag. This is a very old P&C game. The graphics are retro good. Decent music. A juvenile story that hits and misses with the humor intended.

No bugs or crashes, Works fine on Win 7.

This is your typical nostalgia product that is extremely overrated by a few fans. It is funny, but not that much. It's very confusing, hard to navigate, many puzzles are not sensical. If you really like retro gaming, this is a good place to go in your library, but if you lack the patience needed in the 90s for this kind of game, you might like to play something else instead. It includes cards and it's cheap. Very niche game. I can't get myself to recommend it to the masses. Nothing to really hate here, but nothing to really like. So here's a red thumb that's better than a fake blue.

For sure one of the worst graphic adventure games that I have ever played.
Almost all the puzzles have no sense or use strange and artificially complex solutions. Like instead of using an ax to tear down a wall made of unstable and old bricks it will be used a guitar.

The soundtrack is one of the most annoying ever composed by a human being, and when not present will be mostly substituted by farts and burps.
The controls are simply the worst. The main reason that this game cannot be enjoyed is exactly the hardness in exploring the environment. In a 3D environment, you will have to use “Page up” and ”Page down” to look up and down, and the mouse will be used to move your character and pick the objects.

I have also found the graphic style nasty. I liked nothing about this game.

Do not try it for any reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994209007', 'num_games_owned': 1207, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1579508040}
review:
Ein witziges Adventure aus den 90ern, das zur Abwechslung nicht als reines Point & Click-Spiel dargestellt wurde, sondern auf einer ähnlichen Engine wie Duke Nukem 3D und Doom lief. Diese kam auch schon beim großartigen, aber weitaus ernsthafteren und gruseligen [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/292390/Realms_of_the_Haunting]Realms of the Haunting[/url] zum Einsatz.

In einer dystopischen, von "Norm-Polizisten" kontrollierten Welt gerät der Träumer und Taugenichts Kent eher zufällig in den Kreis einer Gruppe Revolutionärer, die das alles überwachende Regime stürzen will. Auch wenn die Story ein eher düsteres Spiel vermuten lässt, ist Normality quietschbunt, witzig und abgefahren. Die Rätsel sind teils albern und erinnern an Spiele wie Monkey Island und Deponia, aber gerade diese ganze Überdrehtheit macht den Reiz des Titels aus.

Grafisch ist Normality ein bisschen ein zweischneidiges Schwert: Während die Umgegungsgrafik aus recht comicartiger Pixel Art besteht, sind NPCs gerenderte, knubbelig-runde Sprites basierend auf 3D-Modellen, die nicht so ganz ins Gesamtbild passen wollen. Richtigen Mitte-90er-Flair verbreiten die zahlreichen Render-Animationen, die es immer wieder zu sehen gibt. Diese sind nach heutigen Maßstäben natürlich furchtbar veraltet, waren damals aber einfach üblich und gehören definitiv zu den besseren ihrer Art.

Leider beinhaltet die Steam-Version nur die eher mäßige UK-Fassung, die Synchronisation der Versionen aus den USA und Deutschland ist um Welten besser. Diese gibt es z.B. auf GOG zu kaufen.

review:
[H1]INFORMACJE[/H1]
Normality Inc. to zwariowana gra przygodowa, w której wcielając się w młodego buntownika staramy się przeciwstawić dziwnemu porządkowi, panującemu w naszym rodzinnym mieście. Za powstanie tytułu odpowiada brytyjskie studio Gremlin Interactive – autorzy takich hitów, jak seria Premier Manager czy trylogia Lotus Turbo Challenge.

Akcja gry osadzona jest w Neutropolis - fikcyjnym mieście przyszłości, gdzie od króluje tzw. „normalność”, a wszyscy mieszkańcy są do bólu poukładani, nudni i przewidywalni. Wyjątek stanowi główny bohater gry imieniem Kent, który rzuca wyzwanie powszechnemu marazmowi i stagnacji. Nasz protagonista postara się odkryć przyczyny tego stanu rzeczy i zmienić otaczającą go rzeczywistość. Jak nietrudno się domyślić, poczynania Kenta nie będą na rękę rządzącej miastem frakcji „Normalsów”, na polecenie której w Neutropolis wciąż dochodzi do zastraszania obywateli, a wszelkie przejawy indywidualności są brutalnie tłumione.

Normality Inc. to przedstawicielka dość rzadkiego gatunku tzw. wacky adventures, gdzie ważniejsze od samej fabuły są podawane w hurtowych ilościach, najrozmaitsze skecze i gagi. Mimo ukazania akcji z perspektywy pierwszej osoby, sama rozgrywka zbliżona jest zasadniczo do klasycznych przygodówek point-and-click i sprowadza się w szczególności do rozwiązywania szeregu zagadek logicznych, podczas których Kent musi manipulować różnego rodzaju obiektami. Absurdalność gry podkreśla dodatkowo jej interfejs, gdyż w trakcie zabawy kierujemy kukiełką głównego bohatera, klikając na jej ramiona, oczy lub usta, celem wykonania określonych czynności.

Pod względem oprawy Normality Inc. stoi na wysokim poziomie. Podczas rozgrywki towarzyszy nam spora ilość prerenderowanych scenek przerywnikowych. Sama gra powstała zaś na silniku popularnego Dooma, tak więc w toku rozgrywki eksplorujemy sporej wielkości, trójwymiarowe lokacje, mając do dyspozycji pełną swobodę ruchu, podobnie jak np. w Under a Killing Moon. author: {'steamid': '76561198025732064', 'num_games_owned': 1251, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 801, 'last_played': 1568499127}
review:
When I was a little lad, my friends and I used to spend a lot of time messing around with the "Adventure Maker" point-and-click games creation software. Being a great fans of "Battle Toads" and similar games, expectedly, instead of actually putting some effort and striving to make decent games, we were hell bent on designing the games to be as hard as possible - and not in the "Dark Souls" fair (or even remotely sane) kind of way. The pinnacle of our miraculous puzzles was the sequence where you had to open the toilet tank lid, pick up the pencil, and throw it into the wall fan to open the door. Makes sense? Absolutely not, and every idea we came up with had the same consistent vibe of absolute ludicrousness.

NORMALITY is similar to this children babbling in a way that it's unique and follows its own set of rules which can seem illogical from time to time. However, the in-game logic, whilst being non-orthodox, is very well structured and self-contained, thus, making the game a hidden gem if you manage to get into its way of thinking and appreciate it, and that's where it differs completely from my childhood creations. This game offers an atmospheric vibrant nostalgic world with a lot of 90s references and some entertaining UK humour (luckily, the Steam version has the English voiceover).

In addition, it has great music, the pixel hunting is absent (that horrid nightmare plaguing so many Russian point-and-click adventure games!), and excellent graphics for its time which holds itself brilliantly even today, thanks to the outstanding art-direction.

And it's cheap and runs on every modern (i.e. > 2005 year) PC.

It'd be unnormal not to grab it!

review:
Tags: Adventure - WC - Walk Clicker
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Puzzle inventory with Day of Tentacle and City of Fools art styles in some sort of first person primitive engine.

This is a story of some oppressive government, ruled by some strange cyborg, that want to remove all fun from society, and control their thoughts through furniture in some sort of run-down dystopian nineties society.

The bulk of the game is played by applying inventory items to hotspots, sometimes pursuing obscure solutions to obscure puzzles, or downright doing things that seem random or unethical.

You get this kind of counter-culture is cool bart simpson sort of juvenile vibe, reminds me a little of The Quivering. Altogether this game is unwieldy, the DOTT puzzle inventory does not mesh with the cinematics or the first person engine really well.

Conclusion: Avoid. This is dated and just does not hold up very well. Navigating the environment is a chore, characters are mostly surface deep stereotype, the story is handled in a heavy handed caricatural manner. You win by making fireworks in the skies and starting a dance party after rehumanizing the cyborg... somehow... by giving him his brain and the cyborg zap the brains with electricity eyes... just... avoid...

review:
READ FIRST!!! *As I have explanation of why it was bad for ME, but MOSTLY good for everyone*

This game was going good, three hours of gameplay, I exited the game *The game was SUPPOSED to automatically save*, as I  did the settings and stuff, and alright, I turned my laptop off, came back.. and well.. Normality was for SOME reason uninstalled.. this literally mean I lost 3 hours of gameplay.. and.. I tried checking the file in steam, it was there, but the application was not there.. this literally means the game IS uninstalled.. so I lost all my progres.. dissapointed in the game.. 

About Gameplay: 
Fun, but controls are pretty hard, but I could understand as it's an old game, the story is also good, I love the story, and the game is tricky, and it's like a puzzle, you would need to use your mind, I do recommend watching some gameplays incase you are stuck at one part of the story, even in some, as it is sort of hard. The game is also so good, as this game is from 1996, it gives you alot of memories.. and it REALLY does give you the feel of those 90's game, note that this game IS from 1996, so it will probably give you that feeling anyways.

Overall Thoughts:
I do want to give it a yes, but because of 3 hours of gameplay progress gone.. and I have to install the game again.. I would have to say a no mostly.. sorry to say.. I really like the game.. and you should buy it.. but if you lose your progress its your own fault *I think most people don't get this problem, only I or some people did.. anyways, a good game.*

Overall 7.5/10 *Because of sudden lost of progress, as well as controls*

review:
Квест-экшен от первого лица с достаточно интересной игровой механикой. Здесь все действия, которые совершает игрок, реализованы в виде куклы, на которой мы выбираем использовать, взять, посмотреть ли на предмет.
Графика здесь достаточно сносная для 1996 года. Конечно, это не Duke Nukem 3D и не Quake, но тоже неплохо.
Головоломки достаточно сложные и интересные.
Сюжет, конечно, немного бредовый, но возможно даже в этом его фишка. Здесь по сути все отдает немного сюрреализмом.

Итог: рекомендуется для любителей адвенчур и квестов, а также для тех, кто любит наркоманский юмор и нестандартное мышление.
6,5/10

review:
Nice (albeit not that new) concept, but overall this game has many flaws.
Basically, it's a 2D platformer in which you control a ball or better, the ball itself moves according to gravity 'cos you can only manoeuver through WASD keys the screen. 
Ok, do you have in mind the application Windows uses to view photos? In the low bar you can rotate them of 90° degrees? That's what this game does. Left and right keys and the ball (ok the game says that's a deformed creature called The Stalker, to me looks like a badly designed ball) will keep on falling or will float in the air while you go from point A to point B avoiding spikes, flames etc.; of course, while you progress other things are added such as mandatory directional arrows, Mario-like fading blocks, exploding tiles and so on.
The game itself is hard and challenging, but overall it's not new at all and it's really badly designed. Every level looks the same, the background is the same and so on. The soundtrack and sounds in general are truly awful.
The controls aren't so buggy but ovearll if this game was free, ok, it would surpass many Flash games out there but since it isn't free, I don't think this will add something to your collection if you've been into these kinds of minimalistic Flash gravity platformers for years. 
Nothing against the game itself or its developers, but I still think that it could have been way more and better refined.
And I mean, the achievements are all dubbed "Compleat Sector".. ok, I suck at English and I've never studied it but.. please, at least have someone review your spelling before publishing a game.. ahah

review:
Interesting adventure game, but it is extremely, extremely 90s.

I had played a ripped version from Home of the Underdogs a long time ago. I remember getting stuck in the  factory area. I do not remember if that version had any voices, but I do remember liking it  quite a bit.

But what I remember the most of it was that during the 90s (97 or 98), when my parents went to a walmart-style store (not a walmart though), there was a PC games shelf.  There were always a couple of game boxes that drew my attention.
There were copies of Redneck Rampage, the Washington DC Duke Nukem expansion, Magebane, Battle Isle Incubtion and... This. 
The cover looked so weird. And the images of the game on the back looked really weird as well.  I was interested in what they showed of the doll interface, I did not understand  for example that the open function on the doll's belly would open the item, I thought that it was referring to actually opening the main character's torso somehow.

Yeah, I dunno.  The box seemed interesting. I never did get  it there since the family PC was not up to par and I actually never asked my parents to get it for me then.

I thought I would never have an original copy of this (and after trying the mentioned HOTU version, did not have all that much interest in it either, the game was not quite as fun as I had imagined back then), but hey, thanks to things like GOG, there are now playble versions of these things that work on modern systems for the most part.

Dunno why, but I  was kind of hoping that it would have mappings for a pad  mimicking a 360 pad, but eh, no such luck. 

Worth trying? Sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018560576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1472588021}
review:
Kosenlos von Indiegala erhalten.

Ich kann die negativen Reviews absolut nicht nachvollziehen, ich finde dieses Spiel mega interessant und halte es für einen kleinen, verstecken Edelstein.

Es spielt in einer Dystopischen Welt in denen eine Polizei-Kraft die sogenannten "Norms" alles kontrollieren, und ich meine ALLES. Spaß ist komplett verboten und Glücklich sein schon garnicht! Die Welt ist ziemlich interessant gemacht und alle Charaktere und Umgebungen reflektieren diese komplett kontrollierte Welt aus der man versucht auszubrechen. Die Welt und ihre Umgebung sind bei weitem das Beste am Spiel. Ich musste mich aber auch überwinden um mich an diesen ekeligen und schmutzigen Stil zu gewöhnen, nachdemd as aber geschafft war hab ich jeden Moment dieses Spiels genossen, allein um zu sehen welche seltsamen Sachen sich hitner der nächsten tür verstecken. Super detailreich umgesetzt 
Welt: 10/10


Die Umgebung ist unfassbar gut gemacht, viele Kleinigkeiten haben gesprochene Dialoge und man kann sich wirklich in diese Welt hineinversetzten, das liegt vorallemd aran, dass man normale Orte sehen kann und wie seltsam sie in dieser Welt funktionieren. Da ist zum Beispiel ein Musikladen in einem Einkaufszentrum,w elcher keine Laute Musik spielen darf. Die Welt ist super interessant für mich aber wie oben schon erwähhnt muss man sich an den Stil erstmal gewöhnen und der Toiilettenhumor der teilweise vorhanden ist ist auch nicht jedermanns Sache. Der Humor ansich ist jetzt auch nicht so sonderlich gut.
Umgebung: 9/10


Die Story des Protagonistern ist nicht der interessanteste Punkt dieses Spiels und eher generisch gehalten. Man versucht als Rebell die komplette Kontrolle den Norms und ihrem anführer zu entreißen. Es ist, um ganz ehrlich zu sein, ein wenig komplizierter als das aber nicht viel. Meiner Meinung nach ist das jetzt nichts außergewöhnliches aber auch nicht schlecht, einige story Elemente die wenig Sinn machen sind dafür ganz witzig. 
Story: 6/10

Das Gameplay ist in seiner Grundlage ein Adventure Point-and-click Adventure, nur dass man sich hier in der ersten Person bewegt. Ich finde das extrem itneressant, da Adventure games mit Echtzeitsteuerung in der Egoperspektive im Jahr 1996 sehr selten waren und die Egoperspektibve eigentlich eher für shooter reserviert war. Das lässt dieses Spiel herausstechen. Ich bin ein großer Fan von Puzzlen und die in diesem Spiel sind ziemlich gut gemacht. Sie sind nicht leicht, aber wenn ich etwas nachschauen musste hatte ich immer das Gefühl, dass ich da auch drauf gekommen wäre und das sind die besten Puzzle, finde ich. Zum vergleich: Myst und seine nachfolger sind um eingies schwerer als das hier, obnwohl es hier auch Puzzle gibt á la "Man werbindet einen Kaugummi mit einer Kugel, damit man sie aus dem Fenster werfen kann damit jemand darüber stolpert", die man eher durch rumprobieren löst, zum Glück sind diese aber eher selten. Außerdem gibt es Red-herring Items die man aufheben kann, aber niemals im Spiel braucht, ich finde das macht die Welt realistischer und die Puzzle sind auch ziemlich gut gemacht.
Gameplay: 6/10

Die Grafiik ist die eines PC Spiels von 1996, sie ist gut genug um alles erkennen zu können und erinnert ein wenig an Duke Nukem 3D mit mehr detaills. Die zwischensequenzen sind erste 3D animationen, die ich persönlich jetzt nicht so hübsch find, mir wären 2D Animationen lieber gewesen, da ich die Grafik sonst wirklich ziemlich gut finde aber ich kann verstehen warum 3D ausgewählt wurde. Ich finde die Grafik  sogar sehr hübsch für eine Welt,welche gewollt hässlich gestaltet ist. ich hoffe das macht Sinn. hübsch-hässlich sozusagen.
Grafik: 8/10

Die Musik ist eher uninteressant. Ich habe das Spiel vor etwas zwei Monaten gespielt und erinnere mich jetzt Spontan nurnoch an das eine Lied in der Möbelfabrik, welches mir immernoch im Kopf festhängt. Sie ist okay, aber nichts woran man sich erinnert oder besonderes. Die Synchronsprecher der Amerikanischen Version sind gant okay bis gut.
Musik und Ton: 5/10

Ich habe unten schon gelesen, dass einige Probleme mit der Steuerung hatten. Ich erinnere mich jetzt nicht daran je probleme mit der Steuerung gehabt zu haben, aber ich meine auch, dass man im Optionsmenü noch das eine oder andere umstellen kann. Kann ich jetzt nichts groß zu sagen.
Steuerung: N/A

Alles im allen hatte ich echt viel Spaß mit dem Spiel und ich empfehle es jedem, welcher Detaillreiche, Dystopische Szenarien mag, Point and click andventures wie Myst mag und mit einer Gewöhnugnsbedürftigen Egoperspektive in einem solchen Spiel kein Problem hat

NICHT empfehlen würde ich das Spiel Leuten, welche dem Dystopischen Szenario garnichts abgewinnen können,  Echtzeit Egoperspektive in Puzzlespielen garnicht mögen und Leuten die immer die neuste Grafik brauchen. Den letzteren Leuten würde ich aber auch noch empfehlen seinen Horizont zu erweitern.

Alles im allem ist das spiel für mich spaßig und extrem interessant gestaltet, daher empfehlenswert.
Gesamt: 7/10

review:
Normality é um jogo de aventura em primeira pessoa desenvolvido pela Gremlin Interactive e lançado em 1996. Neste jogo, os jogadores assumem o papel de Kent Knutson, um cidadão comum que se encontra em um mundo distópico controlado por uma corporação maligna. Nesta análise, vamos explorar os principais aspectos do jogo e fornecer uma análise crítica, destacando os pontos positivos que o tornam uma recomendação.

Enredo e Atmosfera:
Uma das maiores forças de Normality é o seu enredo envolvente e atmosfera distópica. O jogo apresenta uma narrativa intrigante, repleta de mistérios e reviravoltas, que mantém os jogadores imersos na história. A atmosfera sombria e opressiva do mundo do jogo é habilmente retratada, criando uma sensação de suspense e tensão ao longo da jornada.

Ambientes e Design de Níveis:
Os ambientes de Normality são ricos em detalhes e apresentam uma estética cyberpunk única. Cada área do jogo é cuidadosamente projetada, com elementos interativos e quebra-cabeças inteligentes para resolver. A exploração dos níveis é recompensada com descobertas interessantes e segredos bem escondidos, incentivando os jogadores a se aventurarem ainda mais.

Jogabilidade e Quebra-Cabeças:
A jogabilidade de Normality combina exploração em primeira pessoa com quebra-cabeças desafiadores. Os jogadores devem usar seu raciocínio lógico e habilidades de resolução de problemas para avançar na história. Os quebra-cabeças são variados e bem projetados, oferecendo um equilíbrio adequado entre desafio e recompensa. Além disso, a jogabilidade é complementada por diálogos interessantes e interações com personagens cativantes.

Trilha Sonora e Efeitos Sonoros:
A trilha sonora de Normality contribui significativamente para a atmosfera do jogo. Composta por músicas melancólicas e ambientes sonoros imersivos, a trilha sonora ajuda a criar uma experiência audiovisual envolvente. Os efeitos sonoros também são bem executados, adicionando camadas de realismo e intensidade às situações do jogo.

Pontos Positivos:

Enredo envolvente e atmosfera distópica.
Ambientes detalhados e design de níveis cuidadoso.
Jogabilidade com quebra-cabeças desafiadores.
Trilha sonora envolvente e efeitos sonoros imersivos.

Pontos Negativos:

Gráficos datados devido ao lançamento original do jogo em 1996.

Recomendação:

Normality é recomendado para os fãs de jogos de aventura que apreciam uma narrativa envolvente, atmosfera distópica e quebra-cabeças desafiadores. Embora os gráficos possam parecer datados em comparação aos jogos mais recentes, a qualidade da história, dos ambientes e da jogabilidade supera essa limitação. Se você está em busca de uma experiência de jogo imersiva e cativante, Normality é uma escolha sólida.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049916848', 'num_games_owned': 3275, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1460318498}
review:
Normality is a great little classic 3D adventure game that features a fairly cutting edge 3D engine for its time. You can actually move and look around freely with the mouse although the controls take some getting used to (e.g. press both left and right mouse buttons to enable free mouse look). Given its age (released in 1996) that is to be expected but how far ahead of its time it is in general even extends to an autosave feature - yes those were extremely unusual even after almost a decade after the release of this game! The animated textures and level of geometry detail is quite something and while there are sprites for many of the objects and people there are many 3D cutscenes peppered throughout the game.

So, enough about how retro cutting edge it was, the game itself has an interesting story, funny characters and conversations and mostly logical, if at times hair pulling puzzles due to having to find an object in another location to advance, The latter is softened a bit by a fast travel option available from the beginning of the game. The music is quite so-so in general but not really bad per se (we are talking 1996 DOS here). The length is fairly decent clocking in at around 10 hours and it comes with Steam trading cards too. The setting is quite interesting being somewhat a critique of consumer society wrapped in humour.

Would I recommend this game? Of course!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011965365', 'num_games_owned': 2442, 'num_reviews': 2092, 'playtime_forever': 590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 590, 'last_played': 1459703946}
review:
Normality is a very odd combination - an adventure game with a Doom-like engine. Sounds odd? Yeah it is. There are some minor issues with that presentation but I'll mention it when I'll go on...
Normality is a Orwell served with a heavy rock/punk sauce. The titular normality is complete subjection to the ruling government, that means... yeah. No TV other than the boring NORMTV(TM)which runs normal (read: boring) programs for normal (read: boring) people, no rock music, normal books only (anything that isn't normal is of course either censored or disposed off). Hell you can't live in a NORM world eh? Take control of Kent - a young rebellious (or just wanting to have fun) chap and overthrow the boring government! That's pretty much the story of the game.
As for the actual substance - the game requires scanning the environment carefully (Not too careful though, thankfully it isn't a pixel hunt), pick up the puzzle pieces, use them, converse - the usual adventure game stuff. One thing though: the puzzles are HARD. Play on words, tongue in cheek humor or just sheer surrealism is the basis of this game. So watch the conversations! Throwing a spanner in the works might have to be taken literally.
The 3D interface works out... so-so. It's weird and the voodoo doll interface needs to get some using to. Buuuuuttttttttttt... it works.
That's pretty much the best summary: The game works - the dry and quirky humor, the weird control scheme and the revolutionist storyline all goes well together.
5 stars and must get for any adventure game fan. If you're a new to the genre though, reconsider the purchase for it might leave you clutching your head for days, trying to solve a particularly hard puzzles.

review:
The most normal game from the 90s. Normal sound, normal gameplay, normal graphics, normal puzzles, normal retro feeling.

No seriously, even if you didn't play it back in 1996, if you like 3d first person perspective adventure games with graphics like duke nukem 3d, then you have have a big reason to buy this pearl. It is funny, crazy, challenging (a bit of the old unfair vibe is also there, but now we have the internet :-D), nice looking and it has plenty of cut scenes.

The Publisher KISS ldt listened to feedback and will try to bring the other language packs back, that seems to be the only complains from people that played it back than. Personally, I played the game in German so any english version is fresh for me and I can't complain so far.

Some glitched are DosBox issues so far, but it's only a short reinitializing of the resolution which makes me wait 1 few seconds longer till I can get into the menue or an item, but I can life with that, after all, I spend time playing a 20 year old game, what are a few seconds for me :-D.
